The shift towards remote work is likely to have a significant impact on the infrastructure of urban areas. With fewer people commuting to work, there may be less demand for public transportation, which could lead to a decline in investment in public transportation systems.

City planners and developers may need to adjust their plans to meet the changing needs of urban areas. For example, there may be a shift towards more bike and pedestrian-friendly infrastructure, as more people choose to walk or bike instead of driving or taking public transportation. This could include the development of more bike lanes and pedestrian walkways.

Additionally, there may be a shift towards more mixed-use development, where residential, commercial, and retail spaces are all located in the same area. This could enable people to live, work, and shop in the same area, reducing their need to commute to other parts of the city.

Overall, the shift towards remote work is likely to have a significant impact on the infrastructure of urban areas, which will require city planners and developers to carefully consider how they adapt to these changes.
